class_notes:
This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement: -Tradition-Buddhism, Theme. 
To registrar for this course prior study of Buddhism is strongly encouraged. 
This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.
Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will also be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester. The seminar is appropriate for students with some prior background in Buddhism, whether through college courses or self-study. It thus requires the permission of the instructor to enroll.


(Same as REL 354RW 1)
